ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some recorded videos
N/a
We had virtual live lectures, office hours, and peer tutoring hours
Peer tutor hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about linear algebra, matrices, and multivariable calculus (especially for function optimization).

I developed a broad understanding of different topics in multivariable calc as well as its applications in economic contexts. I would recommend this course for someone who is interested in pursuing a field in economics and would like to develop a strong foundation in mathematics without necessarily going through the higher level courses.
I learned about linear algebra and some multivariable calculus techniques
I developed linear algebra skills (vectors, matrices) and multivariable calculus skills (partial derivatives, Lagrange).
I learned about how he efficient in my math work.
I learned about linear algebra, such as operations with vectors and matrices, and multi variable calculus basics
Linear algebra and multivariable calculus

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is organized well and is conducive to learning and problem-solving.
I liked that the classwork and the examples worked on in groups, overall, were reflective of the homework assignments and the exams. This made understanding the concepts behind the questions easier.

Strengths: instruction was well adapted for remote learning; I appreciated very much Prof Ochoa's live writing of notes

Weaknesses: sometimes the professor gives an explanation that isn't clear or doesn't immediately click, and then she moves on. also, we would spend sometimes half the class answering questions by the same person instead of moving on for the rest of the class. class in general was not very engaged and that made me want to be less engaged. finally, we don't talk about the math's applicability to econ

The strengths of this course was that it was INCREDIBLY well-organized, and the tests were very fair. Having pre-typed out notes was very helpful as it allowed students to follow along very well during class. There were no weaknesses of the course!
Strengths of this course were that the pace was very manageable and we could ask as many questions as needed.
I thought this class was amazing! The material was very interesting and the lecture formats were really great and made the class understandable.

Strengths - we had plenty of time to complete problem sets, and Prof Ochoa encouraged questions during lecture. Weaknesses - I felt like the prof was not that accessible outside of class (office hours were really early like 6am). Prof would split us into groups (breakout rooms) but no one would talk really so it felt useless at times

I think we all relied a lot on in-class explanations, and it was no so effective for students to work together on problems over Zoom. If we were in person, perhaps working with other students. I wish office hours and resources outside of class were more accessible. It was really helpful to have so many problems to review, though.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Live writing of notes was successful
Breakout rooms were not very successful because no one would talk inside of them
Having breakout rooms allowed students to work together to solve problems!
Virtual office hours were helpful to gain help on the problem set.
I think if there were sections in addition to lectures that could be helpful.

Working on problems in breakout rooms felt a little like wasting time rather than really learning, because it was awkward and difficult to discuss over Zoom without the instructor readily accessible. In general I think math classes are particularly hard to replicate on Zoom because we cannot follow along on a whiteboard or work together. I think it would have been helpful to have sessions outside of class for reviewing problems, or more office hours available.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially if you are interested in the social sciences. The class is well organized!
I would recommend this course to a student interested in developing a foundation in the intersection between multivariable calculus and its economic applications.
Yes! It gives you the fundamental mathematical basis for econ and it isn't incredibly difficult
Yes! This class made me love math, and I learned so much from the course.
Yes! I loved learning about linear algebra and multi variable calculus!
Yes! I definitely would! This is an amazing course, and the professor is so great! The material is easy to understand and the exams are fair. This class makes me want to take more math classes!
I would recommend this course to a student who wants to apply multivariable calc to economics and other social sciences (our p-sets consisted of various application problems which was helpful)

I think it is a helpful course if you need to learn linear algebra and multivariable calculus, and the material is interesting. Prepare for a small class and a lot of self-teaching, though. In other math courses there are more accessible office hours, resources, and peers.
